newsitem.title: UK: BA denies report of 10,000 imminent job cuts.
newsitem.headline: BA denies report of 10,000 imminent job cuts.

text.p: British Airways (BA) denied on Monday a newspaper report that it planned to slash at least 10,000 jobs and brushed off a report that it wanted to hive off operations so it could focus on flying aircraft and dealing face-to-face with customers.

The Independent newspaper said that under "secret proposals," 10,000 workers would lose their jobs and a raft of BA operations, including baggage and cargo handling, engineering and maintenance and information technology, could be sold off.
A BA spokesman said he had been surprised at the report, which was based on the company's plans -- announced earlier this year -- to save 1.0 billion stg over the next three years.
"It's a surprise that they've put a figure on something (job cuts) where we have made no decision," he told Reuters.
BA said in May that it planned to deliver business efficiencies worth one billion stg by 2000 when it reported record annual pretax profits of 585 million pounds.
The company has also stated that every aspect of its operations was under review to achieve this goal, including commercial, operational and overhead activities.

"At this stage, we are looking at all options available to us," the spokesman added. "We are looking at all aspects of the business. This is what we've previously made public...But we've reached no conclusions whatsoever about how many, if any, jobs will be affected."

The Independent quoted company sources as saying that a new strategy, dubbed "Step Change" by senior managers, would probably mean the sale of the baggage and cargo-handling functions, crew support operations and other activities.

"...the strategy will mean that, within the next four years, BA will simply fly aircraft and provide the face-to-face contact with customers. "All the rest will be sold or split away from the main company as part of management's plan to slash costs...," it said.
Trade union leaders had already asked senior BA directors for a meeting this week, the newspaper added.
The BA spokesman said he knew nothing of a union request for a meeting, saying only that unions had been kept "abreast of this subject all along."

"We are looking ahead while we are still profitable," he stated. "You cannot stand still or you overheads would exceed your profitability at some stage. We're looking at the business, seeing where efficiencies can be made..."
